title: Creating MCP Servers with mcpr
text: Model Context Protocol (MCP) allows Large Language Models like Claude interact external tools data sources. However, R’s stdin handling subprocess contexts requires special handling. mcpr package solves providing Node.js wrapper templates properly manage communication MCP clients R servers.

title: Creating MCP Servers with mcpr
text: version 0.1.0, mcpr supports HTTP transport alternative stdio. HTTP transport offers several advantages: Multiple concurrent clients: Unlike stdio limited one client, HTTP servers can handle multiple connections Easier debugging: Use standard HTTP tools like curl Postman Better deployment options: Deploy cloud platforms, containers, behind load balancers subprocess complexity: Avoids R’s stdin handling limitations

title: Creating MCP Servers with mcpr
code: # Using the convenience function server <- mcp_http(   name = "My HTTP Server",   version = "1.0.0",   host = "127.0.0.1",   port = 8080 )  # Add tools, resources, and prompts as usual server$mcp_tool(   name = "analyze",   fn = function(data) { summary(as.numeric(strsplit(data, ",")[[1]])) },   description = "Analyze comma-separated numbers" )  # Start the server server$mcp_run()  # Automatically uses HTTP transport
